title: How Celebrities Are Reacting to Donald Trump's Transgender Decision
text:
Pissed Off About Trump's Transgender Decision? You're Not Alone. 
But the issue is more complicated than people think. Most Popular By Sarah Rense Feb 23, 2017 On Wednesday evening, the Trump administration withdrew support of transgender bathroom rights protection for students across the country, jumping feet first into a culture battle by sending the issue back to the states. The direct fallout of the decision is unclear, like many of President Trump's chaotic actions—ironic, seeing as the administration cited legal confusion as its reason for lifting the protections. But, as BuzzFeed legal editor Chris Geidner pointed out , a withdrawal is not a reversal. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below By withdrawing, the Trump administration essentially said it has no opinion on the issue of transgender students using bathrooms according to their identity. (The Obama administration was vocal in its support of transgender bathroom rights when it sent its directive to public schools.) It also insisted that the withdrawal "does not leave students without protections from discrimination, bullying, or harassment," according to BuzzFeed . Related Story Richard Linklater Takes on the Texas Bathroom Bill Most Popular Bathroom rights cases are making their way through courts around the county, including that of student Gavin Grimm, whose case will be heard by the Supreme Court in March. Grimm spoke outside the White House during some of the first protests (likely of many) against Trump's decision Wednesday night, as ABC News reports . Transgender student at heart of SCOTUS bathroom case: "We will not be beaten down by this administration or any." https://t.co/yy6wejNc0Y pic.twitter.com/ynv61cyGlo 
— ABC News (@ABC) February 23, 2017 The Human Rights Campaign called the withdrawal a "a blind and cruel attack on young children." Mara Keisling, the executive director of the National Center for Transgender Equality, said, per Fortune : 
Transgender students thrive when treated equally, but too often they are not. These young people already face incredible hurdles in their pursuit of education and acceptance. With a pen stroke, the Trump administration effectively sanctions the bullying, ostracizing and isolation of these children, putting their very lives in danger.
